original_text: The above discussion also lays bare the difference of perspectives between the fusion of hard constraints and knowledge-base merging: the idea of Konieczny and Pino-Perez is to explain the fusion of plain epistemic states, understood as a set of plausible worlds, by the existence of underlying partial orderings or numerical plausibility degrees (obtained by distances), based on axioms that only use plausible sets attached to these orderings. In [67] the same authors use both hard (integrity) constraints and belief sets referring to plausible worlds, and try to extend both the AGM revision and knowledge-based merging. However, they do not envisage the merging of integrity constraints discussed in the previous section. The belief revision and merging literature takes an external point of view on cognitive processes under study. The underlying ordered structures are here a consequence of the merging postulates, but they do not appear explicitly in the axioms and they are not observable from the outside. On the contrary, our approach is to construct fusion rules that only rely on what is explicitly supplied by sources. In the sequel we consider the counterpart of our fusion postulates for ranked models, that can be expressed by means of total orders of possible worlds or by their encodings on a plausibility scale.
original_translation: La discusión anterior también pone al descubierto la diferencia de perspectivas entre la fusión de restricciones duras y la fusión de bases de conocimiento: la idea de Konieczny y Pino-Perez es explicar la fusión de estados epistémicos simples, entendidos como un conjunto de mundos plausibles, mediante la existencia de ordenamientos parciales subyacentes o grados de plausibilidad numérica (obtenidos por distancias), basados en axiomas que solo utilizan conjuntos plausibles adjuntos a estos ordenamientos. En [67] los mismos autores utilizan tanto restricciones duras (integridad) como conjuntos de creencias que se refieren a mundos plausibles, y tratan de extender tanto la revisión AGM como la fusión basada en el conocimiento. Sin embargo, no contemplan la fusión de restricciones de integridad discutidas en la sección anterior. La literatura sobre la revisión y fusión de creencias adopta un punto de vista externo sobre los procesos cognitivos en estudio. Las estructuras ordenadas subyacentes son aquí una consecuencia de los postulados de fusión, pero no aparecen explícitamente en los axiomas y no son observables desde el exterior. Por el contrario, nuestro enfoque es construir reglas de fusión que solo se basen en lo que es explícitamente proporcionado por las fuentes. En la secuela consideramos el equivalente de nuestros postulados de fusión para modelos clasificados, que pueden ser expresados mediante órdenes totales de mundos posibles o mediante sus codificaciones en una escala de plausibilidad.

In [67] the same authors use both hard (integrity) constraints and belief sets referring to plausible worlds, and try to extend both the AGM revision and knowledge-based merging.
However, they do not envisage the merging of integrity constraints discussed in the previous section.
The belief revision and merging literature takes an external point of view on cognitive processes under study.
The underlying ordered structures are here a consequence of the merging postulates, but they do not appear explicitly in the axioms and they are not observable from the outside.
On the contrary, our approach is to construct fusion rules that only rely on what is explicitly supplied by sources.
In the sequel we consider the counterpart of our fusion postulates for ranked models, that can be expressed by means of total orders of possible worlds or by their encodings on a plausibility scale.

original_annotated_sentences:
The above discussion also lays bare the difference of perspectives between the fusion of hard constraints and
knowledge-base merging
: the idea of Konieczny and Pino-Perez is to explain the fusion of plain epistemic states, understood as a set of plausible worlds, by the existence of underlying partial orderings or numerical plausibility degrees (obtained by distances), based on axioms that only use plausible sets attached to these orderings.
In [67] the same authors use both hard (integrity) constraints and belief sets referring to plausible worlds, and try to extend both the AGM revision and knowledge-based merging.
However, they do not envisage the merging of integrity constraints discussed in the previous section.
The belief revision and merging literature takes an external point of view on cognitive processes under study.
The underlying ordered structures are here a consequence of the merging postulates, but they do not appear explicitly in the axioms and they are not observable from the outside.
On the contrary, our approach is to construct fusion rules that only rely on what is explicitly supplied by sources.
In the sequel we consider the counterpart of our fusion postulates for ranked models, that can be expressed by means of total orders of possible worlds or by their encodings on a plausibility scale.
